It means that the entire \xe2\x80\x9cpassage\xe2\x80\x9d processing portion of the model is trained separately on its own task. Once this is trained the passage model is frozen and the rest of the architecture is trained without changing the passage encoder (but still generating and using its outputs for each input). The opposite of freezing the passage encoder would be try to train both the passage and question models at the same time, this CAN create a more adaptable model but comes at the cost of \xe2\x80\x9cmuddying\xe2\x80\x9d the training process where both the passage and question portion are changing their representations to better fit one another rather than just the question model training itself to work well using a preexisting predictable function which creates decent passage representations'

WRITING.TEXT: b'Anything floating on the surface of water being pushed around by waves faster than the wave itself would be considered negative wave drag, the interesting fact here is that the combination of ducklings lining up correctly and the mother moving is an energy efficient way to use waves generated by forward motion to help the baby ducks out.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'No problem! One clarifying thing though, according to the source paper they are feeling a negative total drag, their mother is effectively dragging them along in her wake as long as they are in the correct positions in a line. The ducklings are actively thrusted forward by the total drag force, all they have to do is get to speed with their mother and then they would naturally find themselves at an equilibrium with their mothers+siblings motion(they would need to course correct to not fall out of the wake though). If they were rougher/less hydrophobic the viscous force could dominate but this is not the case.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'There are two main components of drag for vessels on a liquid: wave drag and viscous drag; viscous drag is the drag one would think of in aerodynamics, the act of the trying to push through the viscosity of a fluid. Wave drag is the force felt by \xe2\x80\x9criding the waves\xe2\x80\x9d of the liquid, the force that allows surfers to surf along with a wave. Ducks minimize viscous drag by having hydrophobic feathers and ducklings can naturally be propelled towards their mother by \xe2\x80\x9criding\xe2\x80\x9d the wake of her motion on top of the water. In still water total drag would be in the opposite direction of motion but the mother is supplying a wake which allows the ducklings to get in a formation where each are \xe2\x80\x9criding\xe2\x80\x9d the wave and passing it back to their siblings to ride too, propelling them all forward, this would be an example of \xe2\x80\x9cnegative\xe2\x80\x9d total drag aka >100% drag reduction.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'It actually is negative drag, the ducklings ride down the trough of the wave produced by the mother duck. From the abstract of the source paper:\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen a duckling swims at the \xe2\x80\x98sweet point\xe2\x80\x99 behind its mother, a destructive wave interference phenomenon occurs and the wave drag of the duckling turns positive, pushing the duckling forward.\xe2\x80\x9d'

\xe2\x80\x9cCould this be called a resonant phenomenon? If one wishes to argue, however, that it was a case of externally forced linear resonance, the mathematical distinction between Eqs. (1) and (3) is quite clear, self-excited systems differing strongly enough from ordinary linear resonant ones. The texts we have consulted have not gone this far in explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d

They agree that flutter wrt Tacoma is a qualitative resonance effect, all they are saying is that textbooks tend to give a more basic reasoning related to driven harmonic resonance rather than the true but more complicated explanation, which requires looking into the fluid dynamics of the entire system. WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'When I say \xe2\x80\x9csnapshot in time\xe2\x80\x9d I mean there are actually an infinite number of steps in between the two semi-stable spinning states you are thinking about, each of these steps/states have the same angular momentum and energy. Now as to why we see near instant switching between two states: even though they look stable they are actually unstable points, it just takes a long time for the switch to build up. Since the nut is not spinning on a major/minor axis, little rotations not in the main rotation axis affects the main rotation: stealing some angular momentum and energy (this is allowed because we are not on a major/minor axis therefore there are states nearby with the same total angular momentum and energy), the more angular momentum that gets stolen the quicker the stealing happens, once half way through the switching  the balance shifts and the stealing becomes giving until there is no more angular momentum in the non main spinning axes. It\xe2\x80\x99s all a very dynamic process, the motion from the last step affecting the motion in the next step while spinning in multiple axes all coming together whilst conserving angular momentum.\n\nA slightly different but analogous example is imagine a simple pendulum attached to a point with a solid rod. If the pendulum is balanced upside down perfectly it will stay there forever without starting to swing. Now if a single spec of dust hits the pendulum imparting a tiny amount of force; the pendulum will seem to stay in place but actually is slightly unbalanced, overtime it will get pulled more and more downward, quicker and quicker until it begins to visibly swing. It will swing down and around and right back up to the seemingly stable upside down state; gravity slowly but exponentially amplified the instability created by the dust and switches the pendulum from one semi-stable state to the next. In the spinning nut example the two pendulum states are the two semi-stable spinning states and the gravity that caused the state switching is a complicated interplay between the possible spinning axes of the nut and conservation of angular momentum + energy. Not super ELI5 but hope this helps clears stuff up'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s because there is a smooth \xe2\x80\x9cline\xe2\x80\x9d of orientations with the same angular momentum and kinetic energy, so at every snapshot in time during the flip these two quantities are conserved. Also a small note while rpm and angular momentum are related they aren\xe2\x80\x99t the same, for example imagine two near identical spinning fly wheels that are made of different density materials say wood and steel: the steel wheel has more angular momentum than the wood because there is more mass spinning even though the angular speed is the same. This can intuitively be understood because we all know the steel wheel carries more \xe2\x80\x9coomph\xe2\x80\x9d and would be harder to slow than the wooden one; That\xe2\x80\x99s what angular momentum is, how much \xe2\x80\x9coomph\xe2\x80\x9d is caused by the spinning movement of an object. In general the properties that define angular momentum are the geometry of the object, how the mass is distributed within the object and how it is spinning.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'Yes you can but then in order to simulate for the same total time you must compute for more time steps and thus more compute time. Say you are working with a step size of 0.001 seconds for a total of one second with rk4, in order to get similar error with Euler you would need to simulate with a step size of 0.000000000001 seconds, this is 1000 steps for rk4 compared to 100000000000 steps for Euler; assuming identical runtime per step Euler would take a billion times longer than rk4 for the same deviation'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot generally symplectic\xe2\x80\x9d means doesn\xe2\x80\x99t usually tend to conserve energy, but since the accumulated error is O(dt^4) instead of O(dt) the error term for small time steps (dt) ends up being order of magnitudes smaller. This results in the apparent energy loss taking much longer to accrue using rk4 over Euler method; when working with smaller total steps and steps sizes the energy loss can be a negligible amount in rk4 compared to Euler'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'> But I think that other, surrounding areas of the flag will have had similar amounts of force acting on them, so they all moved together. It was only the bottom-right corner of the flag that moved. 

While yes they will feel similar forces, they will not all feel forces in the same direction, the forces will be radial outwards from the astronaut, so the effective turning forces will not be evenly distributed. This difference in turning forces will cause the dragging I mentioned and also dissipate energy in the form compression of the material, ripples in the fabric and heat formation.

> Do you know how I could do this for, say, the bottom-right corner of the flag? 

Well, the thing about moments of inertia is they are dependant on the total geometry of the object in question. You are on the right track by thinking of just one segment but what moments of inertia allow us to do is take into consideration all these minute pieces of fabric and how they interact with one another, the moment of inertia is defined by summing distribution of all infinitesimal pieces of mass so one can consider all of the object instead of just a corner. (Although intuitively I see where you are coming from, rotational dynamics can be unintuitive and your calculation/model is very very simplistic and runs the risk of being a very bad estimation of the total motion) Using the moment of inertia and the force "profile" on the flag one can determine how the flag shall move as a whole.

> To be honest, I just want to be able to say that it's at least possible that static force moved the flag. 

Oh, there most definitely was a contribution from the static force, the reality is our models are just that, models, all of the possible reasons for the motion described in your source contributed something to the motion of the flag, not just 1 singular thing. But the thing about physics and analyzing phenomena is that most of these contributions can be seen as negligible compared to one or two of the main driving forces in play, physicists often use their intuition and "back of the envelope" calculations to try to determine what could have realistically been the main cause (Although in this case maybe they did run many different scenarios computationally to determine the conditions required for each scenario). In your source they say "not likely", this doesn't mean that there was no static force or that the static force did not cause the motion but that the circumstances in which the static forces were the main contribution (having a 10kV potential difference between the hand and flag for example) is unlikely compared to other options.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'A few things about your general calculations/concepts that I feel would need working on in order to make a full model that I got by skimming your post:

>it's just necessary (I think) to divide this impulse by the mass of the small flag section to find the velocity in meters per second that the flag section would end up with.

This ignores the fact that the flag is one large solid object, while yes if it was just this small segment taking the entire force it would end with a velocity similar to what you calculated given your assumptions we must take into consideration that the flag segment's motion is being dampened and impeded by the fact that it is "dragging" the rest of the flag with it. In order to get a full model of the motion one would need to take into account the dynamics of the flag as a whole, this impulse would propagate and dissipate throughout the entire flag and not just the singular segment which gives much different final velocities/dynamic profile of what's going on.

A better simplistic model one could try using is assuming the flag is a rigid cuboid which can only rotate about the flag pole axis. One can then say that the flag acts as a rigid rod with some spring/restoring force which tries to pull the flag back to its natural resting position (not sure how one would find such a constant simply other than through empirical testing or more advanced 3d simulations of the flag) and the electromagnetic force felt at every segment of the flag. While I do like your idea use of impulses, when it comes to more complicated dynamic systems like this one would probably have to use green's functions to calculate the motion after applying the impulses, it's probably easier to calculate the total energy that the electric force applies and convert it all to rotational energy in this model. By doing this one can calculate the rotational velocity of the flag for any given moment in time (the full dynamics of this simple flag system).

>In the moon's gravity 249 grams would be 41.17 grams.

Mass is a body's tendency to resist motion, this is irrelevant of what planet you are on, the only thing that changes on different planets is the gravitational acceleration felt not the mass of the object so a flag which is 249 grams on earth is 249 grams on the moon and 249 grams on Jupiter etc. as the flag is still made of the same amount of "stuff" which is what gives it its mass, things in space don't lose their mass because there is no gravitational body around, they will still be "resistant" to other types of forces which is what mass is. If one was to use the primitive model I described above you would need to calculate the flags moment of inertia which is the rotational analogue to mass, an object's "resistance" to rotation/torques.

​

But overall I find it unlikely that the static electricity is the cause and the other options outlined in the journal you linked are more likely just due to one fact: the energy that an electric field can exchange at such distances and at such a scale is minuscule compared to the energy it takes to make a 250g flag swing as shown in the video, at least that's what my intuition from working in physics for many years is telling me without doing the calculations explicitly.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'Well the Casimir effect is due to the fact that the \xe2\x80\x98vacuum energy\xe2\x80\x99 between two reflective surfaces is less than between them and infinity/far away. You can think about this via the fact that the harmonics/natural frequencies between two surfaces (the ships) is less than the the number of harmonics between them and open sea. as there are an infinite number of harmonics(all waves are non-destructive). These harmonic waves push the ships, as waves do, but because there are more waves outside the ships than between the ships the ships feel a pressure pushing them together. I hope this explanation works for you but if not don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid to ask!'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'I did my thesis on the Casimir effect, which is a quantum mechanical effect which causes two reflective objects in a field be attracted to one another. During my research I discovered that there is an analogous effect where in any field which allows fields any object which reflects waves in the medium will also attract each other. This included things like ships near each other in the ocean and cereal floating in a bowl. This effect also amplifies what causes Cheerios to attract, at least to my knowledge!'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make much sense as radioactive decay is a quantum effect; alpha radiation is due to the quantum tunneling of helium atoms out of a nucleus, beta decay is due to the weak force (a force described in the standard model which is a quantum field theory) and gamma decay is due to the nucleus dropping from one discrete energy level to a lower discrete energy level (only possible due the quantization of atomic energy levels)'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'Bell\xe2\x80\x99s theorem proves that are no local hidden variables in quantum mechanics and that it is a purely probabilistic theory of physics but being probabilistic does not mean it is not predictable, we can still describe all possible solutions/outcomes of quantum states and attribute a probability to each one as it is the laws of physics itself which doesn\xe2\x80\x99t allow a concrete deterministic solution. While this may seem like it is problematic, it really isn\xe2\x80\x99t; quantum mechanics exists and works because it is probabilistic and no physicists with some grasp of QM would dispute the \xe2\x80\x9crandom\xe2\x80\x9d nature of it.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'We know that the universe is expanding, and the rate at which it is expanding is increasing, we do not know for sure but the prevailing theory is of dark energy. We know that it is accelerating because the second derivative of the cosmic scale factor is positive. This dark energy has negative pressure and causes all matter to be pushed apart. We still are not 100% sure of how it works. As for your analogy with the ball, the ball is going fastest when thrown upwards, once the ball is out of your hand the only forces acting on the ball are downwards. When the ball hits its max height it is at its slowest, 0 m/s, then begins to accelerate downwards due to gravity until it reaches back to where you threw it.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"I hate to break it to you but there is no mindset that will instantly change you from a 2k to 3.2k+, if you have a 27.27% wr in 3.5k mmr there is no way you are really 3k. Best advice is just to slowly improve on your main, it may not seem like you are improving but if you compare your mmrs between a long period of time you will see an increase in skill even if it is only a few 100. The only way to make this go by faster is watching and analyzing your matches and watching informative youtubers, but since you said you do not have much time I assume you will have to take the slow crawl. I'm sorry but this is how most people do it too :("

WRITING.TITLE: b'How could I of won this game?'
WRITING.TEXT:
b"http://www.dotabuff.com/matches/1366558440

(I was windranger)

I played this game where my team was extremely toxic only me and void were non-abusive, everyone kept yelling at each other for feeding, I felt I played mid well enough trying to harass mid, pulling off ganks but none the less the other lanes were feeding even after ganking them successfully, then invoker and axe started hunting chen in jungle where he also fed. Chen demanded he stay in jungle and that no one take his farm, we then got into a stand of mid for a good 10 minutes, my team kept going in one by one slowly feeding I wanted to push other lanes but my team kept complaining about how I should be there to help. At that point I was still doing well, I had lowest deaths and highest kill participation on my team, but when I tried to help fight my team I wouldn't be able to fight off the enemies fed invoker and axe, eventually it was us stuck in our base while they picked us off like flies and tried to wreck us by fountain. I just want to know how I could of helped to win."

WRITING.TITLE: b'How to get chlorophyte ore and any other item!'
WRITING.TEXT: b'I have recently discovered how to change item ids using the bug with piggy banks. If you are unfamiliar with this bug all of your piggy banked items turn into stacked iron pickaxes. The number of pickaxes relate to the items id. Since chlorophyte ore is unobtainable in console editions of terraria. I used this new found knowledge about item ids to do good and obtain chorophyte to start farming it. You must first get a rope and a piggy bank. Put the rope in the piggy bank and reload your world. Check the piggy bank and you should have 965 iron pickaxes (Because ropes item id is 965). Next take away 18 pickaxes from the stack to make it to a stack of 947 pickaxes (947 is the item id of chlorophyte ore). Now reload the world and in your piggy bank and you should have a piece of chlorophyte ore and possibly any other random items. You can do this with any item as long as you have an item with a higher item id. To find all item IDs go to this page http://terraria.gamepedia.com/Item_IDs'

WRITING.TITLE: b'Update bug/glitch list'
WRITING.TEXT:
b'I hope for this to become a list of bugs related to the recent update and all its new content. Please post any bugs or glitches and state for which platform you were on (Xbox/PS3/PS vita) and I will list them here. Overall you should be cautious when loading up pre-1.2 worlds and characters until a hug fix comes out. Please note that many of these bugs may appear on both consoles

Bugs so far:

**Xbox**

-Getting stuck on "Attention! When this icon is visible the game is saving data."

-No chests throughout the underground other than in hell, jungles and dungeons

-Items in piggy banks and chests are replaced by random items (e.g. gold watches, iron pickaxes)

-Unable to connect error when starting up your own pre 1.2 world

-Background will flicker between different images on overworld

-Crimson Hearts(shadow orb counter part) will count as two hearts when broken

-When three crimson hearts are broken the eater of worlds will spawn instead of brain of cthulu(can only be spawned by spinal cord)

-Zombies will sometimes go at about three times the speed when coming on screen

-Bonuses from prefixes on some weapons not shown

-More shadow chests than usual

-No chlorophyte in jungles

-Cannot get new hardmode ore counterparts (titanium etc.)

-Little to no hardmode ores in underground ice biomes

-Mechanical worm drops chance too high

-Cant harvest vile mushrooms

-Cant spawn bosses during rain

**Playstation**

-Getting stuck on "Attention! When this icon is visible the game is saving data."

-Contents of chests and piggy banks can be replaced by random items. Can be fixed by reloading world

-Lag on multiplayer (unconfirmed)

-Loading pre 1.2 maps with campfires will freeze or bug out world

-Glitches with doors

-Shadow orbs drop no items

-Worlds and items deleted randomly

-Bonuses from prefixes not show

-More shadow chests than usual

-Jungle temple can be entered simply by mining the door before defeating plantera

-Upon entering a world tile data may be wrong causing blocks to be on random places

-Lack of chests underground

-Mechanical worm drops chance too high

-No chlorophyte in jungle

Thanks to I_ran_out_idea_s for discovering most of the ps3 glitches

If you would like to get chlorophyte in your world just follw this guide I wrote:

http://www.reddit.com/r/Terraria/comments/23m2q0/how_to_get_chlorophyte_ore_on_terraria_12_consoles/'
